facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 117 of 1953 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil AppealNo. 117 of 1953.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated 29th March 1951 of High Court of Madras in Case Referred No. 44 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 29th day of March, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Madras in Case Referred No. 44 of 1948.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by DAS J. on November 1, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. November 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS J.-

facts.text: High Court answered both referred questions in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from the judgment pronounced by the High Court of Judicature at Madras on the 29th March, 1951, on a consolidated reference by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under section 66(1) of the Income-tax Act whereby the High Court answered, in the affirmative both the referred questions

facts.text: Questions arose from assessment of Mysore Chromite Ltd. for years 1939-1940, 1940-1941, 1941-1942, 1942-1943.

anchor.surface_text: The above Questions of law arose out of proceedings for the assessment to income-tax of the respondent, Mysore Chromite Ltd., hereinafter referred to as the assessee company, for the years 1939-1940, 1940-1941, 1941-1942 and 1942-1943.

facts.text: Assessee company is Mysore Chromite Ltd., private limited company registered in Mysore State, registered office at Sinduvalli.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee company is a private limited company registered in the Mysore State under the Mysore Company Regulations and has its registered office at Sinduvalli in Mysore State.

facts.text: Management and control of assessee vested in Oakley Bowden & Co. Madras Ltd., registered office at No. 15, Armenian Street, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The management and control of the assessee company was vested in Messrs. Oakley Bowden & Co., Madras, Ltd., another private limited company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, having its registered office at No. 15, Armenian Street, Madras.

facts.text: Assessee owns chromite mines in Mysore State, extracts chrome ores, converts to merchantable product, sells mostly outside India.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee company owns chromite mines in Mysore State. Chrome ores are extracted from the mines and converted into a merchantable product and then sold to buyers mostly outside India.

facts.text: Sales to European buyers put through in London by Bowden Oakley Co. Ltd., London, agent holding power of attorney.

anchor.surface_text: The sales to the purchasers in Europe are put through in London by Bowden Oakley Co. Ltd., London, which is the agent of the assessee company in Europe holding a power of attorney from the assessee company.

facts.text: Contracts for sale to European purchasers signed by Bowden Oakley Co. Ltd. in London.

anchor.surface_text: The contracts for sale to European purchasers are signed by Bowden Oakley Co. Ltd., in London.

facts.text: Sales to American purchasers effected through W.R. Grace & Co., who buy for undisclosed principals.

anchor.surface_text: The sales to purchasers in America are effected through Messrs. W. R. Grace & Co., who buy for undisclosed principals.

facts.text: Contracts for American purchasers signed by W.R. Grace Co. presumably in America and by Oakley Bowden Co. Madras Ltd. in Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The contracts for sale to American purchasers are signed by W. R. Grace Co., presumably in America and by Oakley Bowden & Co., Madras, Ltd., in Madras.

facts.text: Price terms F.O.B. Madras or Marmagoa.

anchor.surface_text: Under both forms of contracts the price was F.O.B. Madras or Marmagoa.

facts.text: Provision for weighment, sampling and assay of goods at destination.

anchor.surface_text: Provision was made for weighment, sampling and assay of goods at destination.

facts.text: Buyers open confirmed irrevocable Bankers credit in London before shipment.

anchor.surface_text: Before the goods were actually shipped, the buyers used to open a confirmed irrevocable Bankers credit with some first class bank in London.

facts.text: Assessee ships goods at Madras, obtains bill of lading in own name.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of such intimation the assessee company placed the contracted goods on board the steamer at Madras and obtained a bill of lading in its own name.

facts.text: Assessee draws bill of exchange on buyers' bank for 90% (Europe) or 80% (America) of provisional invoice, negotiates with Eastern Bank Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the assessee company used to make out a provisional invoice... and used to draw a bill of exchange on the buyers Bank... for 90 per cent... payable at sight in the case of European contracts and 80 per cent... at 90 days sight in the case of American contracts and in either case the bills of exchange used to be drawn in favour of the Eastern Bank Ltd., London. The bill of exchange together with the relative bill of lading... was then negotiated with the Eastern Bank Ltd., Madras

facts.text: Eastern Bank Madras credits assessee and forwards documents to London.

anchor.surface_text: Who used to credit the assessee company with the amount of the bill of exchange. The Eastern Bank Ltd., Madras, then forwarded the documents to the Eastern Bank Ltd., London,

facts.text: Eastern Bank London presents bill to buyers' bank in London, gets accepted, delivers documents.

anchor.surface_text: who used to present the bill of exchange to the buyers Bank in London and upon the bill of exchange being accepted the Eastern Bank Ltd., London, used to deliver the bill of lading and the invoice to the buyers Bank.

facts.text: Buyers' bank pays Eastern Bank London.

anchor.surface_text: The buyers Bank in due course used to pay the amount of the bill of exchange to the Eastern Bank Ltd., London.

facts.text: Balance price after weighment and assay paid to Eastern Bank London.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on arrival of the goods and after weighment and assay, the sale price was ascertained and the balance of price... used to be paid to the Eastern Bank Ltd., London,

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed entire profits as arising and received in British India.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts stated above the Income-tax Officer assessed the assessee company on the entire profits in respect of these sales on the footing that they arose and were also received in British India.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the assessment.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the assessment.

facts.text: Tribunal held sales took place outside British India and money received by agent in London, order dated 22nd January 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal by its order dated the 22nd January,1948... came to the conclusion that the sales took place outside British India and that the money in respect of such sales was also received by the agent of the assessee company in London.

facts.text: Agreed between department and assessee that income arose where sales took place.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the statement of case as also from the order of the Appellate Tribunal that it was agreed between the department and the assessee company that the income arose at the place, wherever that be, where, the sales took place.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the profits derived by the assessee company from sales made to European and American buyers arose outside British India?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the profits derived by the assessee companypany from sales made to European and American buyers arose outside British India ?

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the profits derived by the assessee company from sales made to European and American buyers were received outside British India?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the profits derived by the assessee companypany from sales made to European and American buyers were received outside British India ? The above Questions of law arose out of proceedings for the assessment to income-tax of the respondent, Mysore Chromite Ltd.

issues.text: The point for determination, therefore, is as to where the sales took place.

anchor.surface_text: The point for determination, therefore, is as to where the sales took place. Learned Solicitor-General appearing in support of this appeal contends that having regard to the terms of the companytracts the sales must be regarded as having taken place in British India.

issues.text: was there an unconditional appropriation of the goods by merely placing them on the ship?

anchor.surface_text: The question in this case, therefore, is was there an unconditional appro- priation of the goods by merely placing them on the ship ? It is true that the price and delivery was F.O.B., Madras but the companytracts themselves clearly required the buyers to open a companyfirmed irrevocable Bankers credit for, the requisite percentage of the invoice value to be available against documents.

arguments.claim: Contracts are agreements to sell under section 4 of Sale of Goods Act, not sales, as transfer of property to take place later or subject to condition

anchor.surface_text: According to section 4 of the Indian Sale of Goods Act a contract of sale of goods is a contract whereby the seller transfer, or agrees to transfer the property in goods to the buyer for a price and where under a contract of sale the property in the goods is transferred from the seller to the buyer, the contract is called a sale,

arguments.claim: No property passes in unascertained goods until ascertained per section 18

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 of the Act clearly indicates that in the case of sale of unascertained goods property in the goods is transferred to the buyer unless and until the goods, are ascertained. In the present case, the contracts were always for sale of unascertained, goods.

arguments.claim: Property passes on unconditional appropriation per section 23, but here not unconditional

anchor.surface_text: section 23 which lays down that where there is a contract for the sale of unascertained or future goods by description and goods of that description and in a deliverable state are unconditionally appropriated to the contract,

arguments.claim: Seller reserved right of disposal until conditions fulfilled per section 25, despite delivery to carrier

anchor.surface_text: This is further elaborated by section 25 which provides that where there is a contract for the sale of specific goods or where goods are subsequently appropriated to the contract, the seller may, by the terms of the contract or appropriation, reserve the right of disposal of the goods until certain conditions are fulfilled.

arguments.claim: No unconditional appropriation merely by placing goods on ship due to reservation via bill of lading until payment

anchor.surface_text: The question in this case, therefore, is was there an unconditional appropriation of the goods by merely placing them on the ship ? It is true that the price and delivery was F.O.B., Madras but the contracts themselves clearly required the buyers to open a confirmed irrevocable Bankers credit

arguments.claim: Property passed at earliest in London when bill of lading handed over against acceptance

anchor.surface_text: Suffice it to say, for the purposes of this case, that in any event upon the terms of the contracts in question and the course of dealings between the parties the property in the goods could not have passed to the buyer earlier than the date when the bill of exchange was accepted by the buyers Bank in London

arguments.claim: Profits received in Madras as assessee received payment from Eastern Bank Madras on handing documents

arguments.claim: Payment by Eastern Bank Madras was advance on security, not receipt of price; true receipt in London per Prinz Adalbert

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from the judgment pronounced by the High Court of Judicature at Madras on the 29th March, 1951, on a consolidated reference by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under section 66(1) of the Income-tax Act whereby the High Court answered, in the affirmative both the referred questions

arguments.court_reasoning: Not disputed before High Court or Supreme Court

holdings.text: The contracts were agreements to sell under section 4 of the Indian Sale of Goods Act as the transfer of property was to take place at a future time or subject to conditions to be fulfilled.

anchor.surface_text: According to section 4 of the Indian Sale of Goods Act a contract of sale of goods is a contract whereby the seller transfer, or agrees to transfer the property in goods to the buyer for a price and where under a contract of sale the property in the goods is transferred from the seller to the buyer, the contract is called a sale,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of statutory definition in S.4 distinguishing sale from agreement to sell based on timing and conditions of property transfer.

holdings.text: In case of unascertained goods, property does not pass until goods are ascertained per section 18, and here contracts were for unascertained goods.

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 of the Act clearly indicates that in the case of sale of unascertained goods property in the goods is transferred to the buyer unless and until the goods, are ascertained. In the present case, the contracts were always for sale of unascertained, goods.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory rule applied to facts of contracts specifying unascertained chrome ore by description.

holdings.text: There was no unconditional appropriation of the goods merely by placing them on the ship; seller reserved right of disposal under section 25 until conditions fulfilled despite F.O.B. terms.

anchor.surface_text: The question in this case, therefore, is was there an unconditional appro- priation of the goods by merely placing them on the ship ? It is true that the price and delivery was F.O.B., Madras but the contracts themselves clearly required the buyers to open a confirmed irrevocable Bankers credit for, the requisite percentage of the invoice value to be available against documents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 23 and 25 applied: appropriation conditional on payment against documents; bill of lading retained as document of title reserves disposal rights even after shipment.

holdings.text: Property in the goods did not pass earlier than in London when bill of exchange accepted and documents delivered to buyer's bank.

anchor.surface_text: Suffice it to say, for the purposes of this case, that in any event upon the terms of the contracts in question and the course of dealings between the parties the property in the goods could not have passed to the buyer earlier than the date when the bill of exchange was accepted by the buyers Bank in London

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of SOGA ss.4,18,23,25 to contract terms (FOB, credit against documents, assay at destination) and dealing course; property passes at earliest on document delivery in London.

holdings.text: Sales took place outside British India and profits therefrom arose outside British India.

anchor.surface_text: It must, therefore,. follow that at the earliest the property in the goods passed in London where the bill of lading was handed over to the buyers Bank against the acceptance of the relative bill of exchange. In the premises, the Appellate Tribunal as well as the High Court were quite correct in holding that the sales took place outside British India and, ex hypothesis the profits derived from such sales arose outside British India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Property passage determines sale location per agreed principle; affirmed lower courts.

holdings.text: Payment received by assessee from Eastern Bank Madras was an advance on security of bill of lading and draft, not receipt of sale price or profits.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Bank acted as assessee's agent; discounting unaccepted draft with B/L is advance per commercial practice; seller remains liable as drawer.

holdings.text: Profits were received outside British India as price paid by buyers' banks to Eastern Bank London on behalf of assessee.
holdings.reasoning_summary: True receipt where buyer pays seller's agent; Madras advance not price payment; balance also in London; following Lord Sumner in Prinz Adalbert on nature of discounting.

holdings.text: High Court correctly answered both referred questions in the affirmative.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Full affirmation of High Court on both arising and receipt outside British India after independent analysis.

anchor.surface_text: The true position is very clearly put by Lord Sumner in The Prinz Adalbert 1  When a shipper takes his draft, number as yet accepted, but accompanied by a bill of lading, indorsed in this way, and discounts it with a banker, he makes himself liable on the instrument as drawer, and he further makes the goods, which the bill of lading L.R. 1917 A.C. 586, 589.

precedents.cited_proposition: Discounting a draft accompanied by an endorsed bill of lading with a banker constitutes an advance on the security of the goods represented by the bill of lading, with the shipper liable as drawer.
precedents.cited_holding: When a shipper takes his draft, number as yet accepted, but accompanied by a bill of lading, indorsed in this way, and discounts it with a banker, he makes himself liable on the instrument as drawer, and he further makes the goods, which the bill of lading represents, security for its payment.

anchor.surface_text: According to section 4 of the Indian Sale of Goods Act a contract of sale of goods is a contract whereby the seller transfer, or agrees to transfer the property in goods to the buyer for a price and where under a contract of sale the property in the goods is transferred from the seller to the buyer, the contract is called a sale,
In our opinion the High Court correctly answered the second question also in favour of the assessee company.

anchor.surface_text: The question in this case, therefore, is was there an unconditional appro- priation of the goods by merely placing them on the ship ? It is true that the price and delivery was F.O.B., Madras but the contracts themselves clearly required the buyers to open a confirmed irrevocable Bankers credit for, the requisite percentage of the invoice value to be available against documents.
In our opinion the High Court correctly answered the second question also in favour of the assessee company.

anchor.surface_text: It must, therefore,. follow that at the earliest the property in the goods passed in London where the bill of lading was handed over to the buyers Bank against the acceptance of the relative bill of exchange. In the premises, the Appellate Tribunal as well as the High Court were quite correct in holding that the sales took place outside British India and, ex hypothesis the profits derived from such sales arose outside British India.
